author: Aoiyf36
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: I hope they understand that they are making a positive impact on our lives!
body:
I have been receiving treatment on this ward for 7 weeks now and would just like to say that all the staff have been amazing. I came to the Silverwood Ward as I have been experiencing suicidal thoughts, but so far I have been seeing a major improvement within myself, all thanks to the staff here. They have been amazing, as they have been providing the right treatment for me.  
There’s not one that stands out to me, as all of them have played their part very well in my recovery journey. It has taken a while for me to get to where I am today, and although I do have my down days, I know that I have the support of the staff to be open with how I am feeling. What is great about all of them is that any time I tell them how I am feeling, they take their time to listen to me. Even though there are lots of us on this ward, they still make time to help you.  
They do try and get me to participate in activities, but I'm not really interested in them, and when I say this they understand and never force me to do things that they know I will not enjoy. They have been trying to help me become more involved with these things, but we are taking small steps at a time.  
The food so far is good but would like to see more of a variety available as it can be boring when it’s the same thing over and over. My room is very well laid out, it is cleaned regularly and kept the way I like it. Most importantly the bed is very comfortable!  
The communication between me, the doctors and nurses has also been excellent as they speak to me on a level that I am comfortable at and will understand. I would also like to say that I am very grateful for the support that they have been providing to me, and I understand that their job isn’t easy treating us, but I hope they understand that they are making a positive impact on our lives!

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Conen65
title: Long wait for appointment
body: Urgent referral made by GP to neurology after my brother with a brain injury experienced 4 sudden unexplained falls. Sadly 5 weeks on he has heard nothing. Not even a letter acknowledging delays.

author: centauruskd98
title: Excellent examples of their profession
body: Yesterday I was admitted to the Surgical Unit 1 at Grantham and District Hospital for a stent removal, having had one fitted in July. I have to say that right from the start I was treated with absolutely brilliant care - I was made fully aware of what was going to happen at each stage. Although all the staff that I came into contact with were excellent - caring and friendly, I would like to give special thanks to Maggie and Mark. Although at times rushed off their feet they never let their standards drop and were courteous, caring and had quite superb sensory of humour. At a time when Nurses are being asked to do ever more, they are excellent examples of their profession - thank you.

author: indusrf43
title: A steroid injection into my hand
body:
I have been experiencing pain in my middle finger joint for a long time, but it had become so bad it was painful in everything I did. After an x-ray which showed it was bone on bone, I was referred to St Michael's.  
The lovely doctor I saw was so friendly and helpful. She was kind, gentle and tried to help in every way she could. She said she thought a steroid injection might help, but not guaranteed. In the meantime, she gave me advice on how to strap it to limit the pain. I received an appointment within 6 weeks.  
The injection itself was painful, but I was warned about that. It's been one week since the injection, and my finger has stopped hurting totally!! I am amazed and delighted. The doctor told me it might or might not work, she also said there were no guarantees on how long it would last, but for the time being I am pain free.  
The hospital and every person I met in the two visits I made were professional, caring, thoughtful, smiling and lovely. I cannot praise the NHS enough. Too many people complain, not enough give praise. I totally respect these people who work to help others - in fact one nurse was working on her day off.

author: marwy59
title: I’m leaving a new woman
body:
After a spell of feeling unwell, I found myself in loane house ward 1, but I have to say I couldn’t have been sent to a better place. The staff were amazing, couldn’t do enough to me and nothing was ever a problem.  
I’m departing today, but I will miss the friendly staff. The ward is very therapeutic and relaxing with things to do to pass the time.  
I’m leaving a new woman would just like to say a big thank you!

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: redfn55
title: Coil replacement
body:
Went in. Explained everything that would happen and went through consent. The 2 in the room were AMAZING!! talked me through everything and even told me before they did anything.  
Explained how it would feel and really made me feel at ease.

author: marwy59
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Amazing staff
body:
I have been in ward 1 about 3 weeks after having a fall, the staff here in the hospital are very nice.  
The food is excellent, and the staff were amazing. I loved to see the lady in the orange shirt, she brought me things to do, wool knitting needles, magazines, and sometimes just a cup of tea and a chat.  
I’m leaving ward 1 today and will miss the friendly staff.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: corvusze83
title: Treated with respect and dignity
body:
As a family we wanted to give feedback to Dalhousie Ward - an amazing ward that we have been part of for 15 years. Our daughter spent long periods in and out of the hospital and it was this ward (formerly ward one at old hospital) that we spent our time on.  
Sometimes our stays were over 6 weeks, or longer.  
The care, dedication, respect you received as a parent , and also the patient was amazing.  
The ward could not of been anymore caring for the situations and how ill our daughter was on occasions.  
It was a very busy ward dealing with children with complex needs , respiratory issues and numerous other illnesses .  
The staff always ensured your child received the best of care , whilst working a very busy and changing and challenging ward.  
Due to our daughters illness we were in a cubicle /room so for us we had the peace and quiet from a very busy ward .  
The play specialist ensured we had whatever we needed for our daughter , lights , books etc and she would come and sit with our daughter to let me out for a coffee, or it was just nice to have a chat with her and someone to speak to about our daughter.  
As a family we built up a great relationship with this ward, and the staff are like an extended family. As our daughters health deteriorated the staff were there for us and again so supportive and ensured we were alright. In January this year our daughters health took a massive turn for the worst , and my father in law passed away at the same time; life was hard. Dealing with a lot of emotions , what it showed us was the staff are just human like everyone else , yes they have a job to do but they are human as well,  
I remember one day the ward was quieter which was very unusual, and the staff bathed our daughter. The music and laughter from that room was something we hold as great memories, the staff were getting time to be with their patients and enjoy the fun times  
The staff came in to express their condolences, and ensure we were alright. They managed to get us into Ronald McDonald so we could be together as a couple and take a minute from the ward, to get to our daughter something - we were ever so grateful.  
Our last admission was in July and the staff were aware that our daughters health was on a very thin line , it was upsetting as we knew we probably wouldn’t be back at the hospital again which was hard to accept .  
Our daughter passed away in August at home , and it was an honour to have a lot of the staff at her funeral , people that mean so much to us.  
We have also been back to visit the ward as we will never forget 15 years of our life we’ve spent there .  
The ward is run very well, patients needs are at the forefront, the staff are dedicated and work very hard. The charge nurses are there on hand to support and help when things get tough - a great way of working .  
These people are not recognised enough for the hard work , dedication they provide on a daily basis. We certainly take our hat of to them and can’t thank them enough  
Also would like to thank A&E who ensured that we got the best of service on admission. As we were mostly 999 in to hospital they ensured we were treated as soon as possible. And to Castle Mey wards where we have spent time, again treated with respect and dignity, and again they work so hard  
Thank you to the Sick Childrens Hospital in Edinburgh, new friends for life. We will never forget what you done for us as a family.

author: Appreciative Nigel
title: Positive experience in A&E
body:
I was taken in to A&E by ambulance  
I have prostate and bone cancer, there was concern that I had Spinal Cord Compression. Waited just one hour. The ambulance guys were absolutely brilliant.  
Although waited in the corridor for a while I was looked after very well, cups of tea, sandwich, biscuits.  
The medical staff were super, a credit to the NHS (all of us, in other words). WELL DONE EVERYONE!

title: Awful experience
body: In the first session, I was mainly sobbing or mute, barely managing to get the words out to describe what had happened to me (and the panic and paranoid delusions it had caused). After this, the counsellor more or less wrote it off, saying, Well, bad things do happen to us in life and we just need to learn to cope. In the last session I had before I quit, I dared to wonder aloud whether my social anxiety might have to do with my explosive parent, and the counsellor snapped back: “I’m not a psychologist; we’re not here to analyse.” I had only made this comment because the counsellor had told me they thought my paranoid behaviour was linked to my relationship with my parents... And afterward, when I told the counsellor that I’ve been suffering from anxiety attacks since I was 13, she suggested we talk about the circumstances in my life at that time that could have induced the attacks…go figure. I felt so confused about what exactly this “talking space” was for, having got mixed messages left and right, which left me feeling humiliated, rejected and more depressed than I was at the start.

author: Falconer 1
title: A job well done
body:
I had a pre-op assessment carried out by Jo at the Vale of Leven Hospital, I’ve had a lot of dealings with various departments in the NHS over the last 2 years and always been very happy with the staff and the treatments.  
The way that Jo conducted the whole assessment was simply brilliant, she made me feel so at ease and made the whole process actually enjoyable, this was a perfect example of a person doing their job as good as it could be done.  
Thank you Jo 🙏

author: wyliem02
title: I do not take their work for granted
body:
I woke at 7 a.m. with a pain in the chest, and after a few moments it grew gradually worse instead of better. I rang for an ambulance. After the initial 111 was repeating automated COVID procedures, 1hr and 10mins later the ambulance crew arrived and took BP and ECG. They were very reassuring and of great comfort. I was taken to the Ulster, but waited in the ambulance while staff consulted with the ambulance crew over a second ECG. I was then rushed to the RVH.  
I was taken to the Cath-lab, and a line was inserted in my wrist. I was told I was having a heart attack at this stage and they were clearing a clot. I had felt the effects of previously administered morphine, so I was drowsy and felt no pain or discomfort.  
Once stablised, I was moved to a room and given a COVID test, which unfortunately tested positive. I found out in the days that followed that it was a S.C.A.D and I had a congenital condition that would be investigated further with an MRI at a later date. I remained in a ward with other patients until I was moved to room in the Ulster.  
A cardiac consultant doing the rounds had planned a CT scan, but only realised I had tested positive for COVID when I told him. The tests were put off until I received 2 negative lateral flows. All tests were inconclusive, so when I was discharged a few days later, I was told I would need to go back in September for CT and ECG .  
My stay at both hospitals was comfortable and anxiety-free, given the circumstances. The nursing staff were kind and considerate. In the weeks that followed I was reluctant to do anything, as I didn't know my limitations or what damage was done by the torn artery. When I went back in September to the Ulster, I was given the all clear from the S.C.A.D. It had made a full repair. I am still on the waiting list for MRI.  
During my stay at the Ulster, I was told that I would be contacted by cardiac nurse Roisin in the Downe Hospital to schedule a bleep test and possible rehab. I embraced this, as I knew it was the motivation I needed to being healthy again. The environment was ideal, as I was placed in a session group with other individuals, who in my opinion had endured much more serious events.  
Throughout the 8 weeks, Roisin and her team delivered a friendly session that consisted of exercise and tutorials that informed and motivated me and gave me the confidence to improve week after week. I am still mindful of my S.C.A.D event and wait for the MRI with more curiosity than dread.  
In a few weeks I hope to be referred on to Phase 4 of the Cardiac Rehab, where I would be increasing the activity level for a longer period of time, and build it into a lifestyle choice rather than a hurdle to overcome.  
I am very grateful for Roisin, her team, and all of the NHS staff that have so kindly devoted their time and energy into recovering patients like myself and others. I do not take their work for granted, and I hope I do not require their assistance again for quite some time.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust
Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: Coraline
title: Excellent care from an ambulance crew
body:
Really appreciated the kind, calm and professional response from the ambulance crew - Jason and Tom - who came out to my mum last night.  
They were quiet, and gentle, and patient. They listened carefully to what had happened, and her history. I felt that mum was very safe in their hands, especially when her condition changed en route to A&E and they made a decision to divert to a specialist stroke unit.  
Safe, effective, person centred care at its best. Thank you.

author: enid1965
title: Hospital porters and bed waiting times
body:
Went to Urology Dept at the Queen Elizabeth for a kidney infection following stone removal. Long story, but to get to main points: waited 7 hours for a bed. So, the first bit is to do with getting to the ward, a very nice volunteer got me a wheelchair and took me to Urology, so why can’t they take you up to the ward? An 80-year-old man who also waited all day was told 90 mins for a porter? A lovely nurse took me up herself, as the wait for me was an hour. Volunteers are there, and plenty of them.  
Second bit is the discharge process. It was a weekend, so I expected a delay, but I was told I was going home at 10 a.m. But I wasn't out until 5.30, due to the wait with the discharge letter and prescription. There were about 9 of us on that section waiting to go home, 9 beds that could have been allocated to other patients. Imagine that multiplied all over the hospital.  
Now, I know why people have to wait so long, this had nothing to do with the elderly who can’t get home. I was told it's the same every weekend, not so bad during the week, you usually get out by 3. Still, a long delay. This could make a huge difference to the ambulance waiting times.  
It’s just really scary that something that to me sounds easy to fix isn’t done, maybe a doctor on a few hours overtime at weekends to make sure discharges are completed by 1 p.m. The knock-on effect is huge. The staff themselves in the hospital were absolutely fantastic at all times.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: Knee Girl
title: Day case at HollyBank, Cannock
body:
Had surgery to left knee, and was treated with so much care and respect after.  
Nothing was too much trouble for any of the staff.

author: Nunu73
title: Removal of coil and implant put in.
body: Very pleasant experience. No pain, no discomfort, very happy.

author: statuskk93
title: Total knee replacement
body: Had a total knee replacement at Cannock Hospital. The treatment I received was excellent. The Staff went above and beyond to care and help. Nursing staff/doctors/HCA/all staff, especially on Hilton main, were extremely friendly and helpful, nothing was too much trouble. Food was lovely, ward clean. Overall I had a lovely positive experience. Thank you to all.

author: cathdarlo02
title: I felt completely reassured
body: I had to undergo some tests and was naturally nervous. I was looked after by Dr Sarah, Nurse Rachel and HCA Val. The staff in the department were amazing! I felt completely reassured and was informed in the most caring way everything that was going to happen. I didn’t feel embarrassed at all, this made the whole experience much easier for me. Thank you for your care and for making me feel reassured.

author: laureenjo02
title: They are my heroes
body:
Recently had my son 8 weeks early and he was in NICU at Ulster Hospital. I have to say they were the most amazing people ever. The care and support they gave not just my son but me too was amazing. They always made me feel at home when I was there each day. I will forever remember all what they did for me and my son.  
They are my heroes.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: heronyp97
title: Covid + Flu vaccination
body: Really friendly and efficient team at Lynebank hospital from walking through the door to getting my vaccines. I was put at ease from the start. The centre is very well organised, with plenty of parking.

author: xraywj98
title: My Husband's Care
body:
At home after a cancer diagnosis. Could not get up felt dizzy and black tarry stools I was very upset and worried. Called ambulance. Team arrived led by Jenny. They put my husband at ease as he was agitated they also helped me calm down a bit.  
Taken to A@E. In there a good while, while a bed was found. We were then put onto au2. This was over the weekend.  
A nurse called Marina gave great support to us however no investigation or procedures were carried out here over the weekend.  
Then we were eventually moved to ward 52. They did an endoscopy straight away and found that the stent that was fitted was bleeding top and bottom so the problem was sorted in Ward 52.  
All of the team have been do helpful as my husband ended up having a heart attack and was moved to a side room.  
Amy who was looking after my husband was simply amazing. Kept his dignity intact in a difficult situation. Nothing was too much effort.  
The whole team in this ward delivered outstanding service too, making me pots of tea as I was on the ward all day. To giving my husband constant care and updates do he knew what was happening and what the next stage of the process is.  
We are still in ward 52 waiting for a bed in the stroke ward and I hope the team have such excellent standards as ward 52

readBy.name: Office of Murdo Fraser, MSP for Mid Scotland & Fife

author: Lou1987
title: The staff here were all lovely
body:
Sent by the GP with fast heart rate, and I was admitted onto the EAU Ward. I was feeling really unwell as well as scared, as my heart kept going up to 170 bpm.  
I was in for 3 days while they did a number of tests, the staff were all really friendly, and watching them with other patients, they toileted the elderly all in a timely manner. The nurses would chat to me at night when I was being kept awake by other patients, having a laugh to lighten the mood and help with the long nights I was having.  
This is the 3rd hospital I had been in regarding my heart, and Grantham was the first hospital that wanted to sort this out, knowing they couldn't leave me in the state I was in.  
The staff here were all lovely. Nothing was too much trouble with the staff on EAU.

author: AEF87
title: Diversity
body:
I attended for a growth scan and antenatal appointment and was disappointed by a member of the teams lack of awareness. The scan had been booked and I was told I would need to see the consultant afterwards but I wasn't given a letter or appointment time to see the consultant or informed I would first be having a BP check and urinalysis. When I was called I assumed I was going to see the consultant so my wife got up and came with me. As we approached the staff member said it was just the patient who should be coming in and explained this was just for BP etc. which was of course not a problem.  
The staff member then proceeded to ask if we were sisters to which I replied no this is my wife. I understand that it wasn't said with any ill intent but I'm sure they wouldn't say to a male and female attending are you brother and sister which shows a lack of awareness. If they had apologized and left it at that I would have shrugged it off but the staff member then went on to say we really looked alike and could be twins which I found entirely inappropriate. If this staff member saw a heterosexual couple both with brown hair and blue eyes would they also assume they were siblings and upon finding out they are a married go on to say they look related?  
I could tell from the persons manner and tone they didn't mean to cause any upset but it did still upset me. It might seem trivial but when things like this happen it makes you feel like you have to validate your relationship. It's also a very odd thing for someone to say you look like you are related to the person you have married. I think some improved education on diversity and understanding the impact of situations like this would be beneficial.  
[Very unhappy with 'Staff attitude']  
  
[Very unhappy with 'Explanations']  
[Very unhappy with 'Seeing the whole me']

readBy.name: Office of Alexander Burnett, MSP for Aberdeenshire West

author: andrewsd09
title: Rodent ulcer removal
body: Very welcoming and reassured by Kirsty and Laura. Kept me informed throughout the whole procedure. All done in 30 minutes. Highly recommend these 2 lovely ladies to reassure that all went went. Thank you so much.

author: bluedj95
title: Wonderful friendly people
body:
After 3 weeks in hospital with damaged knee and severe breathing difficulties I was able to come home with a care package. The staff were wonderful ensuring I had everything I needed.  
An exercise programme was devised and help given to me to follow it.  
Wonderful friendly people I cannot thank them enough.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: Annre88
title: Waiting time
body:
Hello  
I have been waiting for dermatologist appointment for nearly 6 months since I have been referred from my GP. I have been struggling with face acne for over 10 years. I have tried lots of different treatments and antibiotics. The GP has decided that they can’t help me anymore and referred me to get a specialist help - unfortunately I’m still waiting and my depression is getting worse because of the scars and painful spots.  
I’m getting really low with my mood as I was hoping to get treated with success. Now I’m only giving up on hope and the waiting time for an appointment has made me really anxious 😥

author: DJenna
title: She is amazing at what she does
body: I got physical therapy with Michaela in Altnagelvin Hospital after my 4th wee boy. I was so nervous, as I'd never been to one before, but she was so lovely, and made me feel so comfortable. On the next session, I felt I could ask her anything, which was brilliant and I felt much better. Last session today, and I couldn’t have done it without her lovely personality and making me feel so comfortable. She is amazing at what she does.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: Shagq75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Outpatients is fine but the parking needs sorted.
body:
The parking here is an absolute disgrace, it near made me late for my appointment. I have never been here before yet it was okay to find, with the signs directing me to it. The place is clean and well-kept just by looking at it.  
The staff are very kind from what I have gathered, even watching them interacting with other patients you can see their friendliness.  
Outpatients is fine but the parking needs sorted.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Martin G
title: Day Surgery Experience
body:
I had surgery on my left wrist.  
I just wanted to say that the staff's kindness and care from the moment I arrived until I left were phenomenal.  
I can only remember some name: Lorraine (nurse I believe), Livingstone ( anaesthetist - I couldn't remember his first name, sorry) and Ms Phillips (Surgeon). All exceptional.There were others but apologies, I can't remember their names.Again, a massive thanks for all the help and how at ease they made me feel.

author: redcs67
title: Given choices for my hysteroscopy
body:
I recently had a hysteroscopy at Southmead Hospital and had been concerned about pain, especially as I had experienced pain during the initial examination of my womb. The doctor and I discussed local anaesthetic but she proposed a technique to try first which used water to open the neck of the cervix. While I had some minor discomfort/cramping it was not painful, and meant I didn't have to recover from the local. I felt comfortable with the way it was handled and did not experience the pain I had feared.  
I was also able to choose a female doctor which made the appointment less nerve wracking.

author: williamsj55
title: The attention I received was excellent
body: I lost consciousness twice after a pill became stuck in my throat and was rushed to hospital. The ambulance took me to A&E. I was admitted and the attention I received was excellent. The staff were superb and many test were carried out before I was released. By then I was feeling fine.

readBy.name: University Hospitals of North Midlands NHS Trust
Plymouth University, BSc (Hons) Urgent and Emergency Care 2022

author: Lina B
title: Epilepsy nurse led clinic
body: I was happy and looked after well.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust
Ulster University, Faculty of Life and Health Sciences

author: Gerard164
title: Epilepsy Nurse Led Clinic
body: Happy with Sandra and treatment, quick effective service.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Vanrg56
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Treated with respect and politeness
body: I'm so impressed with the professional way I've been treated, with respect and politeness and useful information, really happy to have you all looking after me.

readBy.name: Southern Health Mid & North Hampshire Division

author: pelicanjy84
title: Using Inclusion Thurrock Services
body: I was referred to Inclusion Thurrock by my GP at a time of real crisis. They were extremely patient and understanding, providing practical advice at an appropriate pace. I found all those I came in to contact with at the service very professional, but also caring and easy to talk to. I received cognitive behavioural therapy which worked well for me. At the end of my one-to-one therapy I was offered group sessions that I attended remotely, giving anonymity and allowing me to fit it around other commitments. It also provided a good interim level of support before complete discharge from the service. My experience with the service has been extremely positive and I would highly recommend.

author: hadargt78
title: Telephone appointment
body:
Towards the end of telephone call from haematology l heard my nephew speaking on the phine instead of haematologist. I quickly explained l was on a call and ended the call . At that point l think haematologist did try to call back but due to shaky and numb fingers l was unable to answer the call. On trying to return the call, l believe incoming calls were blocked and so I called the secretary. She said she would call him but later called to say she couldn’t reach him on phone. He would call at her office later and would let him know the fault was entirely mine! I reassured her that we just about finished our conversation.  
All of this was professionally and courteously handled as usual by Crosshouse Dept of Haematology…but when l finally managed to contact my nephew and asked why he had called me, he said “l didn’t call you; you called me! I am still underneath a tractor trying to find out why it ain’t working!”  
Numb fingers do make phone-calls a problem and l apologise for all the inconvenience caused by this, to the busy team at Crosshouse.  
I hope l do better next time!

author: Shetland lass
title: Great service and care
body:
Having a parent with hearing loss is challenging for them and the family. When something goes wrong with their hearing aids it is dramatic and leaves them in a silent, frightening world.  
Fern, who works within the Audiology Department, is so caring and compassionate, making sure that hearing aids are fixed and returned as soon as possible with little fuss.  
I just want to say a huge thank you for a service which can make such a difference to someone's life.

title: Musculo- skeletal expert :)
body: I was referred here by my own practice to see the above expert. He was knowledgeable, patient and reassuring, asked lots of questions and examined my hand thoroughly. I was really impressed with the whole experience. Thank you NHS!

author: rainse49
title: High value contact
body:
Although the practice is facing all the challenges of contemporary circumstances, not only did the doctor ring with all the information I needed following an emergency hospital admission, but the practice receptionist chased the hospital discharge summary which the hospital had failed to forward to them, so that the doctor had all the admission and prescription info to hand when he did so.  
Helpful, cheerful and efficient contact going the extra mile.

author: Colww35
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: A good experience
body:
Was transferred from DHH to RVH, then back to DHH Male Medical. Took too long to find out what was wrong with me, but it could be down to different hospitals, one saying one thing and the other saying another.  
But now I am in DHH Male Medical I have been given a warm welcome. The doctors and nurses are great and I feel as though I am getting somewhere at last with my care and looking forward to getting home.  
Food not good, but I can't complain about that. The staff at DHH are very clean and tidy and the ward is spotless considering the amount of work they do and staff shortages. They deserve a lot of credit.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: puppisyh55
title: The competence of the team was inspiring
body:
Truly exceptional service and quality of treatment that I couldn't have dreamed of receiving in the days beforehand, whilst anticipating the event:  
Just back from a skin lesion excision that was causing great anxiety, before the procedure, based on past conversations with one or two other people that had had similar procedures (elsewhere).  
The friendly atmosphere at the hospital put me instantly at a better level of ease, but the competence of the team was inspiring, making a frightening prospect less uncomfortable than a visit to the hairdresser, quite frankly.  
I hope the team concerned get to read this, because they should know that their work was exceptional, especially the surgeon.

title: Outstanding practice
body: Hopkins Ward , all staff were polite, professional, supportive and helpful. I felt safe and well looked after and would like to thank everyone involved in my care.

title: Great Service
body: My husband and I attended for our flu and covid booster vaccinations today.  As always excellent and caring service.

author: Taylortwo22
title: Adult Occupational Therapy
body:
Lawrence and Lucy have been most helpful. They have arranged for hand rails to be fitted to my bathroom, and they are currently arranging for maintenance to my wheelchair and some visits from the District Nursing service to dress my leg.  
Unfortunately the response from the latter two services is a bit slow.

title: Inaccessible service
body:
today tried telephoning the practice for an appointment with concerns following surgery. After 30 mins, gave up on the phone gave up and decided to walk round to the surgery in my village, only to be confronted with a sigh to say that, due to staff shortages the surgery was closed today. the message said that Withernsea was  open. drove to Withernsea surgery, to be advised by the receptionist, that they were not making bookings for appointments as their quota was  exhausted, and none would be available for 3 weeks. I would therefore have to attend daily at 8.00am in the hope an appointment became available. I therefore decided to try my luck with the internet, as recommended by the telephone message playing when I initially phoned. Couldn't access the website because it was being "blocked" by some advert for a company that offers internet services to g.p. practices, with no way round it.
No wonder A & E is always crammed to the rafters

title: Good practice
body: I was seen on time for my apportionment and the nurse explain to me about the procedure and was very pleased with the outcome.

author: CPSCPS
title: Such wonderful treatment and such a lovely welcome
body:
I required to attend the sexual health clinic at Ninewells today. There has always been a stigma linked to gay men attending such services, and due to this I have always had anxieties and fears about how I will be treated and how people will look at me.  
Well, today completely washed the fears away. I was totally not prepared to receive such wonderful treatment and such a lovely welcome from the staff in the department. All of the staff are a real credit to the team and the service. I believe it was Sandra who contacted myself to arrange an appointment, she provided me with any information needed and was able to answer any questions I had, absolute kindness and compassionate displayed on the telephone.  
Then I was treated by Sarah today, absolutely outstanding how she made me feel. I can honestly say I came away feeling quite emotional (happy) because of how genuinely kind, caring and compassionate she was. I cannot thank you enough for how you made me feel today.  
Keep up the good work, it doesn’t go unnoticed. Today's experience has given me the confidence to attend without worrying

title: Outstanding practice
body: Hopkins Ward , all staff were polite, professional, supportive and helpful. I felt safe and well looked after and would like to thank everyone involved in my care.

title: Outstanding practice
body: Hopkins Ward , all staff were polite, professional, supportive and helpful. I felt safe and well looked after and would like to thank everyone involved in my care.

author: alpharm74
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Altnagelvin Area Hospital Orthodontics
body: Staff are very pleasant and easy to talk to. They are extremely understanding of my worries and it is lovely to have that support.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

title: Poor facilities, poor service
body: My partner was admitted to lgi from Jimmys, since coming here it has been an absolute shambles, lack of communication from staff to patient, and it would appear each other. no call button in his room for three days even though it was reported straight away when he shouts for assistance he got told off for shouting, call button finally repaired only to go faulty again in the same day. poor facilities in the toilets for anyone disabled, have to bring in own cutlery as hospital doesn’t provide utensils for people who require the larger grip cutlery. Bed not changed for two days even though there was blood on the sheets. Would I recommend this hospital No, you would stand a better chance at the Pdsa, or go to Jimmys , as for contacting Pals to assist with complaints don’t bother they are about as much use as a chocolate fire guard, they say they will look into it and get back to but this is like waiting for a phone call from god it never happens, the nursing staff try their best but can only do so much. If I could rate LGI as a minus I would.

title: Great care
body: Staff always helpful and friendly, great care as always. Not always easy to get an appointment but patience with the system of booking an appt is a must.

title: Great practice and caring staff
body:
As usual, I was met with a smile from the reception to the treatment room.
Everyone is kind and makes sure that you feel at ease.

author: funnybz68
title: Advice about adjustments to bathroom
body: My wife is diagnosed with Alzheimers and I requested advice about any necessary adjustments to our bathroom. Lucy arrived on time and conducted a full interview about our needs and concerns. She examined our bathroom and bedroom and offered suggestions to consider. I found Lucy to be knowledgeable, competent, friendly and her manner very reassuring. I would have no hesitation in recommending her to anyone who felt they needed advice.

title: Fantastic treatment
body: We cannot thank the staff enough for dealing so quickly with my husband. He was seen within minutes of attending A & E and quickly identified he was having a heart attack and was given pain relief then was transferred by ambulance to Wythenshawe (all within an hour) where a team were waiting for him and a stent fitted.  He is now recovering at home.  Thank you so much NHS.

title: Very knowledgeable and professional nurse
body: I was nervous about my procedure today but the nurse I saw was very experienced, informative, professional and knowledgeable. I felt listened to, my wishes were respected and the procedure was successful.

title: Brilliant Caring Staff
body: A big 'thank you' to the surgeon who fitted a stent and all the Acute Coronary Care Unit and f2 staff who looked after my husband after he was admitted with a heart attack.  He was quickly transferred from Royal Oldham to Wythenshawe where the team were waiting for him for his op.  His whole experience, although frightening at first was made better by his treatment and the care of the staff.  Also brilliant food!  Thank you all.

title: great team
body: Found the staff on reception very polite and helpful on answering my queries. The doctors are very understanding and give you the time to fully explain you problem. The waiting room is comfortable,light and well ventilated.

title: Faultless
body: Easy online system to book in on arrival. Calm, environment and seen quickly and thorough time spent with the Dr.  As always it was faultless.

title: no complaints
body:
Every contact/visit to the various surgeries has been positive.
 I do find the on line booking etc to be rather complicated for anyone who is not too clever with using on line contact, but still better than trying to get in touch by phone.
All staff are polite, caring and patient. Especially when pressure on them is so great.

title: An amazing practice
body: I can't thank the staff enough for their care, patience and kindness during my eye operation. Everyone was just wonderful and put me at ease straight away.  Their efficiency was amazing, even down to the taxi service provided.  Would highly recommend.

title: Fantastic care
body:
I attended A&E for a bleed in early pregnancy, and the team could not possibly have been any more sympathetic, understanding, professional and caring. I was very surprised at how quickly I was seen. The reception team were compassionate and discreet, the health care assistants and nurse went above and beyond to make sure I felt as comfortable as possible, and I was reassured and kept informed every step of the way. I saw a very caring and professional gynaecologist, and was referred for an urgent scan later that afternoon (it was past midnight when I was seen). 

This was the best experience I have ever had of using an A&E department, I was so much calmer and felt reassured after leaving, and I felt every single member of staff I saw genuinely cared about me - despite the pressures they were under and how busy the department was. Thank you, Chesterfield Royal Hospital.

readBy.name: Chesterfield Royal Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Brilliant surgery
body: Fantastic experience at spa medica. Kept me well informed about cataract surgery from pre op to going into theatre. Staff were thoughtful and kind. I was really worried but they put my mind at ease at every step. Thankyou to all the lovely staff at spa medica Liverpool.

title: The NHS at its best
body:
I’m not a regular user of The Allen practice but whenever I need a consultation or a referral I’m so pleased to be registered with you. Available, professional, listen, considerate, understand next steps and take action in a timely manner.
At anytime one could not expect more, during these times I can only thank you….you are a role model for “best practice “

author: encryptionts96
title: The communication was awful
body:
My husband had a planned operation for a brain tumour on a Friday morning. All went to plan, the doctor phoned to tell me, which was good. That's when it started to go downhill.  
No one ever phoned to keep me informed, so unless I rang I was not told anything on his progress, and you don't like to keep ringing staff as they are really busy, but you do need to be informed about a loved one.  
My husband phoned on a Tuesday morning to say he had a scan, all was good, and he was being discharged. No one phoned all day to actually tell me this, and as my husband was a bit confused, I didn't know what to believe - we live 150 miles from the hospital, so you cannot just up and go.  
I had to ring the hospital to find out he was being discharged that evening at 5 p.m. on a dark, cold night. They sent him home via hospital transport. The communication was awful. We are under an immense amount of stress as it is without this. Very annoyed

author: Jellybean1970
title: They made me feel at ease from beginning to end
body: Just want to say a huge thank you to the ENT Department, especially consultant Antonio and nurses. From finding a lump in my neck, to having it removed, they made me feel at ease from beginning to end.

author: Saltlake2
title: The basic patient care was lacking massively
body:
I was admitted into A&E by ambulance with signs of having Cauda Equina Syndrome, when 2 days before I was at Out of Hours when a doctor sent me home giving the condition I was in and unable to walk. In A&E 2 days, and the care I was given was horrific.  
I was left to sit in a porter chair for over 9 hrs, left in a corridor after being violently sick in the waiting area due to the pain I was in, and by being sat down when I suffered the most pain by sitting. The staff in A&E were very defensive and rude when asking a general question about having some pain relief, or when I would be seen, explaining the pain I was experiencing being sat on the chair etc and I needed to lie flat. I was eventually taken into the treatment, 9+hrs later I lay on the bed without a blanket (it was so cold) and no pain relief for hours.  
I finally saw a doctor who was amazing. Checked me over and booked me in for an MRI for the following morning. I wasn’t offered any water or food before my cutoff time for fasting. I was left alone the entire night and following morning in the treatment room.  
Morning came and it was time for my MRI. I got to x-ray department and I struggled to get off the chair as I hadn’t been giving any pain relief. I was back out and had to wait on a doctor to come and give me some morphine to allow me to move and get up onto the table to proceed with the MRI. I was then told straight after my MRI what my results were and was told time was critical and I would be taken to Ward 12 and an emergency ambulance will be arranged to take me straight to Edinburgh Royal DCN to undergo emergency surgery.  
B12 was absolutely ridiculous, they didn’t have my bed ready and I was left to sit on a chair within the ward for a while. Once my bed was ready I got into it and was told by my consultant what was happening next, which was the emergency transfer to Edinburgh.  
In the meantime, I asked to use the toilet as I hadn’t been in over almost 20 hrs, but I wasn’t allowed out of bed. I was offered a bed pan. Staff didn’t protect my dignity and were very unprofessional. I struggled to use the bed pan due to not being able to feel any parts of my body from my waist down. I explained I couldn’t feel the bed pan or feel I even needed to go. I was worried I would wet the bed. The staff nurse told me it would be very degrading if I happened to do that and the bed would need changed, etc. I was taken back by their comment. I asked them to removed the pan and I would just leave it and wait till I got to Edinburgh.  
I felt so violated and my dignity ripped away from me. Now I was still in B12 until 11 a.m.-5.45 p.m. Time was against me! What happened to the emergency ambulance transfer? I then overheard the paramedics talking to the staff when they were here to collect me asking if I was large, which I’m not, but to overhear professionals talk like this was appalling!  
The condition I have meant there was a key moment of having surgery which was 24-48 hrs. Having out of hours, A&E and B12 delay all of this really has had a huge impact on my recovery. Where is patient care? Where was the compassion and understanding of patients worry and fear?  
While I fully appreciate all units are understaffed, the basic patient care was lacking massively. This will sadly be a time of my life I won’t ever forget, and I just wish A&E, Out of Hours and B12 had a lot more compassion for what they do.

readBy.name: Office of Michelle Thomson, MSP for Falkirk East

author: Mozzy
title: Treatment in ED
body: I was referred to the ED at the Ulster with suspected sepsis. Because of referral, I was taken straight away and treated with IV fluids and antibiotics. I was there for 4 hours and I have to say I felt very well cared for. I noticed the staff were very much under pressure ,but this did not affect their caring attitude, thank you so much

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: StM18a
title: Welcoming and kind
body: Attended podiatry appointment at Armagh Community Clinic, Tower Hill this afternoon with my son for nail surgery. The podiatrist and health care worker were very welcoming, and very kind, putting him at ease, with plenty of humour along the way.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: LRxx
title: Monklands A&E / surgical recieving
body:
I was referred to A&E from my GP with query appendicitis. Waiting time in A&E wasn’t too bad, and I was triaged by a nurse who told me I was to go to the surgical receiving ward ( I believe this is ward 4).  
I was then left in the corridor on a porter chair in A&E for over an hour, waiting on a porter to take me to the ward. Multiple members of staff walked by me asking what I was doing there because it was odd I was just abandoned. Eventually someone called for a porter again as they think I had been missed & I finally got taken to a ward.  
On arrival to the ward, there were no staff around, and so the porter just told me to sit in a bed and let the nurse know I’m here whenever they appear. The porter then left. I sat for over an hour without anybody appearing - not a nurse , a doctor, a CSW, nobody around to even say hello to. Bear in mind, I had been up all night screaming in agonising pain, and while the pain had settled now, I was not offered pain relief & not one single person asked how I was.  
Eventually, a student nurse arrived to do my obs and my admission paperwork, but halfway through got called away by a nurse to get something for them. This student was behind the curtain with me doing my admission, I felt this was unprofessional of the nurse to interrupt them for something trivial. I was then left again for 2/3 hours, not a nurse about to ask what was happening. I didn’t know if the doctors would come round, or was I waiting on a scan or bloods.  
At this point I was so frustrated on the phone to my partner crying , I was so tired and sore and scared. A nurse saw me upset and didn’t even come to ask if I was OK, just stared at me and then left. I have never been in a hospital as a patient before and all I wanted was someone to explain what was happening. All I needed was someone to say hello and explain what I was waiting for. Finally a nurse arrived and took my bloods and so I waited for the results.  
When a doctor finally arrived, they said my bloods were fine and they didn’t suspect appendicitis but something gynae related. They took my gynae history, which is when I explained I had experienced this pain multiple times before and so I didn’t think it was my appendix, to which they asked whether I thought it was partly my fault this hasn't been dealt with before. I have been to multiple GPs and had scans previously for this pain, but nobody can seem to get to the bottom of it, so I felt this was extremely rude and insensitive to a young girl who is clearly distressed after experiencing the most traumatic day.

author: smn95
title: Acorn Centre - tongue tie assessment unit
body: I was having trouble bottle feeding my three week old - as this clinic normally looks at breastfed babies I wasn't sure how my issue would be handled. Patricia and Pauline couldn't have been more welcoming and understanding, my worries had been for nothing. They assessed my son and gave suggestions as to how I could improve feeding with great help and demonstrations. Despite this being an extremely busy clinic these ladies helped me and my son as much as they could.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Geo69
title: Given my confidence a boost
body: I have been attending for hydrotherapy. It has improved my movement & posture & also gave my confidence a boost

author: giraffetz69
title: Labour/ward care/breast feeding support
body:
We were so looked after and well informed from start to finish and the staff throughout my labour were brilliant, was a bit of a blur for me but I'm sure the midwife who birthed our girl was Olivia and she was so attentive, lots of laughs in between the crying and the screaming!, I was then taken to ashgrove where again the care followed through, I was looked after by a lovely midwife called Natasha and again so sweet and caring. The ward staff were lovely and very attentive, however if I had one complaint was in the night, I was very tired so I buzzed for some support with feeding and they took a long time to come and when the lady did arrive. She told me just take my baby to the breast and she left and as a new breast feeder and new mum I was a little taken back by this, so I sat with baby a bit lost if I'm honest.  
The next day, I had a midwife Hannah and she was just as lovely as the girl the day before. I spoke to her about my feeding, and she gave me lots of good advice and put me forward to the infant feeding team, I thought great. I then met the lovely Amy who was so lovely, she spoke about hand expressing which I was completely useless at but got me going, and I felt so confident and positive, sadly it was the end of her shift, but she gave me that first little confidence boost, which was so very needed.  
The night-time came and again I felt extremely scared, she wasn't feeding still and again I buzzed for support this time a lady (no name showing) and physically put my baby on, given my little girl fed but there was no help given really, I felt as if I was disturbing them, so that was the 'quick solution'. Next day I was eager for home but my midwife Hannah again suggested some help again from the infant feeding team, this time I seen Tyler, she was also lovely, she sat with me during a feed and really boosted my confidence, I expressed that I felt a bit uncomfortable with the position I was using which was rugby ball, so she introduced me to the laid back, never heard of this before but gave me so much freedom and allowed me to really relax and enjoy my feeding. They really made me feel heard with my feeding, the night staff over my stay I feel just gave the 'can't be bothered' attitude which is a shame really because the day staff were the complete opposite.  
Overall my stay was really positive and I can't thank the Ashgrove girls and the feeding team enough, you really are all angels!!

author: Baby Jack
title: I felt I had arrived at a five star luxury birth spa
body:
We arrived in ninewells on a Sunday for an induction. The ward was busy and noisy and a little frightening. It took two days before I was ready to be taken to the labour ward. I was in an anxious state. Full of fear.  
Upon arrival in the labour ward, I have never felt so well looked after in all my life!  
All the midwives, Doctors and anesthetists we're so exceptionally kind and tolerant.  
The care I received from absolutely everyone was extraordinary. Such wonderful people that I felt I had arrived at a five star luxury birth spa. I was waited on with such accommodating patience and compassion!  
My 3rd baby, and terrified of labour. I was desperate to have an epidural immediately. Which I was given.  
The babe was born quickly and was in full health.  
I was desperate to get home to my other children.  
In the middle of the night, everything was arranged so that we could be discharged.  
The cup of tea given at the end of labour was even given by the most lovely caring person.  
And even delicious reviving gluten free toast given from an overly generous midwifes personal supply! (I'm a coeliac)  
Such accommodating and lovely people, we will be forever thankful. And eternally grateful.

author: jazzze37
title: No reasonable adjustments at gender identity clinic
body:
I got a letter inviting me for a second assessment at the Sheffield gender identity clinic in late November 2021. I was excited to come to the appointment, since it was already about 4 years since I was referred by my GP. However, the appointment was at 9:00 am and due to a disability I take medication that makes me drowsy in the morning. Since I live far from Sheffield, travelling to get to the appointment on time on this medication was just not possible for me. So I contacted the clinic to ask for a reasonable adjustment: for the appointment to be either online or rescheduled to an afternoon. I was assured that that would happen.  
It is now a full year later, and I still have not heard from the clinic. I'm shocked that they simply do not make a reasonable adjustment for disability and instead just act like I cancelled the appointment for no reason and should wait over a year for the next one.

readBy.name: Sheffield Health and Social Care NHS Foundation Trust

author: The roses
title: My husband and my care after being involved in a fire
body: We were involved in a fire on Saturday morning. From phoning 999 and how quickly the services got to us gave us treatment and got to Aberdeen a &e was incredible got seen in resus and got given amazing care, my husband got moved to the burns ward and they have been outstanding to my husband and myself l. We were up on holiday and have done everything and more they could for us both in the most terrifying week of our lives. The doctors nurses and clinic staff in plastics department who have dealt with me and my burns were fabulous. I don’t even have the words to express the care we’ve both received it’s been phenomenal.

author: Gilnr75
title: Experience of poor care
body:
Following my mother being advised that 1/2 her lung would need to be removed due a tumour being found, she was referred to ERI from Borders General Hospital for the lobectomy procedure. She was advised to be at Outpatients for noon the day before her operation. Staff there were very helpful and friendly and the whole pre-op process was very slick and efficient.  
Unfortunately, she was advised at 15:00 that there were no beds on her Ward, 102, so she would need to spend the night in a Day Procedure Unit. She was then moved to a TV room within the ward to wait until the day patients were away, which eventually was not until 19:00.  
During this time, I waited with her as she was extremely anxious about the operation, and not helped by all the uncertainty of where she would spend the night. During our wait she was offered the last and only meal, which turned out to be cold curry with under-cooked rice.  
At around 18:00 I asked a ward nurse if she knew roughly when my mum would be taken to a bed, and was advised grumpily that they were not a Band 6, so wouldn't be getting involved. I am sure the same message could have been communicated in much more friendly and professional manor.  
The operation went ahead and I would like to say that both the surgeon, the anaesthetist and the HDU staff were great, sadly after that is where the standards fell considerably.  
During my mum's time on Ward 102, when she asked for help with anything, she was regularly advised that they were short-staffed so would need to wait - often the help never materialised or she had to wait over 2 hours including when she was in a soiled bed. Sadly, very little care or compassion was shown during her 4-day stay.  
Generally, the standard of food was exceptionally poor, meaning that she either felt hungry of her family had to take food in for her.  
We hope that staff understand the impact these negative experiences have on someone who is recovering following surgery.

author: mckennak02
title: Day clinic Withers Ward
body: We were seen straight away, very well informed, and staff first class

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: Tentsmuir
title: I know I am in good hands.
body:
A year ago I was recommended to get a check for Prostate Cancer following a urine infection. Thankfully I followed the recommendation and I was diagnosed with the cancer. I had the Prostate removed by Robotic Keyhole Surgery in February this year. The Perth & Dundee Urology Team were tremendous throughout, explaining procedures, answering questions and being kind and supportive. Graham, the specialist nurse, was particularly kind, and helpful throughout, helping me through a very difficult time in my life. All went well and I have been in good health since.  
After a blood test at my local health practice I was recommended to get a Colonoscopy and I had this done at Ninewells in Dundee at the end of November. As before I was more than a little concerned about the procedure and outcome. The team at the Ninewells Colonoscopy Unit were very kind and helpful and the procedure went very smoothly and happily I had no discomfort afterwards. I am currently awaiting the results of Polyp Analysis but given the professionalism and caring attitude of all the NHS staff who have dealt with me during this period I know I am in good hands.

author: beidep64
title: Breast Mastectomy professionally cared for
body:
The care at St Michaels especially St Joseph’s Ward under the amazing Kristina was awesome so professional, friendly team Debbie is a delight, and the unit was spotless they made a traumatic experience amazing.  
Chantal in Recovery was fab when I asked for a biscuit to help blood pressure chocolate bourbons swiftly arrived. The surgical team under Professor Drew very professional friendly from Mr Ming to Carly. Clare my anaesthetist was especially helpful with asthma and advice. St Joseph’s is a fab modern unit thank you all. xx

author: Stumpy78
title: Sexual partner had positive screen come back
body: Trying to call the sexual health triage department local to my home all where cancelled so drove to Cowbridge as closest. Staff where extremely helpful and dealt with me promptly, professional, compassionate and with humour.

author: J124
title: Parking and location
body: Parking is really bad at Seven Fields Health Village, also no other options or very limited.

author: Eosinophils
title: Gastroscopy at Victoria Hospital, Kirkcaldy
body: I had this procedure done yesterday. I decided to take the throat spray rather than sedation. The team worked superbly. Confident, comforting, reassuring. It could not have been better! Therapeutic touch well used and much appreciated.

author: waltzyw65
title: Very good care at the hospital after slip on leaves
body:
Early November my husband slipped on wet leaves and damaged his right arm. I took him to A & E at about 20.00 hours, he had an assessment by a triage nurse within 5 minutes of arrival, he was sent to Urgent Care where he was seen by a Nurse Practitioner within 10 minutes, she checked him, gave painkillers and sent him for an X ray, then back to the Nurse Practitioner who was very efficient and reassuring. She gave him a collar and cuff sling, painkillers, leaflets and an assurance that the Orthopaedic team would be in touch in the next few days. We left the hospital 2 and a half hours later. Fantastic service.  
Two follow up appointments a week apart were face to face appointments and X rays and again conducted efficiently by a Nurse Practitioner who was very experienced and reassuring.  
This all seems very good practice and you are to be congratulated for this. Well done.

readBy.name: York and Scarborough Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

author: betacx38
title: Poor patient care
body:
A family member was recently an inpatient on ward B4 at the Beatson Hospital. As a family we were very disappointed in the level of basic nursing care provided; this included personal care and response to buzzers. Whilst an inpatient there was no offer of support for a shower or even provision of a basin to allow for a wash and shave by the bed side when not feeling well enough to mobilise to bathroom. Sheets were left unchanged on occasions unless done so by family. Orders for meals varied hugely at times a meal was said to have been declined, this happened on one occasion when the patient was sleeping but in fact a family member put a request in. If the same family member was not there the following day lunch would not have been provided. This is basic care that should be provided at a high standard at all times.  
When admitted to a ward it is important that patients can contact staff at all times, therefore a buzzer system is in place. Our experience of the use of buzzer is disappointing. It was often turned off without a response by the ward staff, messages for pain relief were not passed on to nursing staff and requests for assistance to mobilise to the bathroom were ignored. Often assistance was required due to medical equipment being connected or waiting to be disconnected all outwith patient control.  
There is a huge emotional impact being an inpatient at the Beatson, basic care and words of reassurance go a long way in supporting families and ensuring patients are at ease during their stay, unfortunately this was not our families’ experience with the Beatson.  
On the contrary medical care was of a high standard and were very caring and compassionate. We met a senior nurse who also portrayed these values of care and compassion.

author: mattyinnorth
title: 6 week course of immunotherapy hayfever
body:
Immunotherapy hayfever;  
They started the process by checking vitals before and after injection, this was done by checking for blood pressure heart, peak flow meter, and body temperature. Which was all recorded.Upon the 6 weeks course they found I had stage 2 hypertension and as a young adult in my late 20's, they notified my GP, and suggested to speak to my doctor.Without treatments like these, this will decease my life expectancy and increased the cost to NHS for preventable diseases, illness.  
After the vital was check, then we discuss introduction, review and corrections actions and once approved, the gave me dose with an injection.  
The doses were within the tolerances, so I could return to work. Which I was happy about. Its clear the nurses involved are competent and communicate to do the task, required of them.  
30mins after the dose, my vital were checked again and recorded.  
In conclusion  
I would say,  
The ward meets a lot of quality management standards.  
Which is great to see.

author: branhd53
title: Asthma clinic / services
body:
My son has been treated under Dr Grier for the last few years in relation to asthma. The level of care received has been great both during the lockdown stage of the pandemic and since.  
Dr Grier has a wonderful approach with kids - talking to them about their condition (rather than addressing questions to parents) and explaining it in age-appropriate language. This has ensured an empowering and positive experience for our child, and helps to foster his sense of ownership of his condition as appropriate for his age.  
Dr Grier has a warm nature and has created a very safe environment for my son, meaning he looks forward to his hospital appointments. We have felt supported on the journey to stabilising my son's asthma. Appointments were at times beyond the 3/6 month review period, but we were encouraged to get in touch if his condition had changed or had any concerns, so didn't feel these delays had any negative impact.  
The clinics themselves feel very well organised and efficiently run. All staff are professional, welcoming and supportive.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Simo78
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Women's Group - Gosport
body: We would like to see a women's group to address particular issues or to meet outside the hub with other women from the service for coffee and a chat

author: Abit Stiff
title: Appointment was not saved on the system
body:
Apparently, my previous appointment at the physiotherapy clinic was not save correctly on the booking system. I arrived early for my appointment, knocked on the door as requested and sat in the waiting room.  
Not long after my appointment time ,staff dismissed the patient I presume with the timeslot before me, however they didn't check the waiting. I knocked on the door a couple more times without response and went and sat back in the waiting room for 30 mins.  
One staff member came out to call for another patient that arrived after me, and so I asked to check if they had an appointment for me. 15 mins later, another staff member appeared to call another person who arrived after me with an appointment scheduled after mine.  
I asked again what was going on with my appointment, and was told that because the booking system is very old, that the appointment wasn't saved correctly and I would have to come back again the next month.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

title: Car parking
body: I had an appointment this afternoon at the Pre-Op assessment centre. I had great trouble trying to find out how to pay for parking, although the receptionist kindly told me. On leaving I missed the payment machine and when I re-entered the site, I discovered the machine but it then told me I had nothing to pay. I was on site for about an hour and would like to pay what I owe.

title: Impossible to get an appointment
body:
Phoned up last Friday at exactly 8 o'clock
To be told I was number 19 in the queue, I continued to hold as I was ringing for my wife who had suffered a prolapsed vagina 23 minutes later the receptionist answered only to be told there were no appointments left and to take my wife to the A and E. 7 hours later my wife was finally treated by a doctor.
What is the point of having a system that is not fit for use either get more lines or staff to answer the phone. I have to phone the surgery again next week to get a referral for out patients department we will see if I am successful or not. Not impressed and would never recommend this practice to friends or aquatences.

author: Simo78
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Women's group - Gosport
body: I think Gosport Inclusion would benefit from a women's group. Women have specific traumas and exploitation which can lead to addiction.

title: Communication and Attitude Issues
body:
Have been at this practice since I was born in 1964 it bears no resemblance to the caring helpful surgery it once was
I have two long term health conditions which are managed by Sheffield Teaching Hospitals very well but this Gp surgery does not read their letters look at the results reporting system and repeatedly ask me to have repeat blood tests which have already been taken at the hospital there is just no joined up service here now
The drs talk over you will just not let you tell them what has happened it is like they are not interested even though you might know more about your condition than them
I was recently told that I was lucky to have had several covid vaccines as I’m immunosupressed I would not consider myself to be lucky at all with a chronic condition
I am a health professional and I know more about the NHS than most, know what bloods I need when and do not appreciate being asked to have them repeated at this Gp because they cannot look on the hospital reporting system!
When you call for an appointment it is like you are asking for an hours consultation you barely get 5 mins on the telephone the receptionists want to know all your private business and it’s just not appropriate to ask patients the questions
Recently they lost blood pressure readings I was asked to take in and asked if I would do them all again I am speechless
Please stop talking and treating long standing patients or indeed anyone like cattle we deserve a bit of compassion and care
Listen to the patient please
Tick box exercises do not make for good care 
And perhaps open earlier and later so appointments can be accessed for shift workers
Please don’t just take repeat medications off the online system so they cannot be ordered as this can stop important medication being obtained in a timely manner
Thankyou in anticipation of change

author: woodpigeoneb57
title: Waiting for referral to ENT
body:
In 2016ish and before Covid I had what I called pre- Covid. I had to go up to emergency PRI on Boxing Day. I had all the Covid symptoms breathing, crackling lungs, throat. Given inhaler. Lost voice for 6 weeks. Months later noticed left ear hearing very poor. It went from hearing to muffled hearing. Referred to PRI ENT twice and Ninewells once. Each time told by reception they had no knowledge of appointment, yet I’m standing there with appointment letter. The ENT Head Nurse felt sorry for me and took me into ENT to see my left Ear on Computer. They said I had a blocked Eustachian Tube and would emergency refer me to PRI ENT.  
At the time I was told all PRI phone calls go via Kings Cross Dundee before being transferred on to PRI.  
By this time it’s 2018/19. I went to PRI ENT - the consultant who took a 5 second look in my ear and told me it was my age. He was so disinterested. I was only 68ish. I was gobsmacked! Shellshocked! I went home and thought about it. I was going to complain, but the Covid pandemic started and so I just left things.  
I’ve had ear trouble since 5 when schools regularly health checked. It took the fifth Consultant at the old Dundee Royal Infirmary to realise I went deaf whenever I had a sniffle. The late wonderful Mr Brennan, Head of ENT operated on both my perforated ear drums with huge success in the 1970’s. I attended ENT annually until Mr Brennan retired so I know procedures extremely well. PRI seemed to stop doing annual ear checks on perforations.  
Now Covid is controlled so I phoned my GP surgery to try and get a referral to Ninewells ENT. Unfortunately GPs will not see patients so I’m waiting for a GP to call me at the start of December.  
Meanwhile I got a free hearing test at “Hidden Hearing.” Excellent hour of tests and information. Yes my left ear is poor, but my perforation operations are first class. However I am not paying several thousand pounds for hearing aids. I’m hearing well, though obviously fairly poor in left ear. I want to find out about this left ear and blocked Eustachian Tube.  
Might I say I have always had first class service from all the Nurses, Doctors and Consultants at PRI every area I’ve ever had to go too. I’ve been visiting ENT since I was 5  
During the Covid Pandemic I accidentally tripped over my garden pond stones. I was in agony with my left ribs. I contacted my surgery and after speaking to a GP he asked me to come into the surgery. From there he thought I might have broken a rib and told me he’d ask for me to be X-rayed. A couple of weeks later he phoned me to say PRI didn’t want to give me an X-Ray? I bow to their superior knowledge.  
I think there is just so much pressure in Hospitals, I quite understand. I love my NHS and all the work you do. Thank you.  
So that’s my story.

author: purdieml02
title: Fertility treatment
body:
After being referred to the Edinburgh Simpson Reproductive Centre for infertility, we were placed on a waiting list for IVF treatment. The wait was not long, and within a few months we began treatment.  
The staff were so kind, informative and supportive. Without them it would have been a much more difficult journey.  
Our daughter was born because of all the hard work that the Simpson Centre had undertaken to make our wish come true.

author: Rhojm87
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Kept informed by Orthodontist
body: My appointments were quick and easy which made for a comfortable experience throughout my treatment. My Orthodontist would always make sure I was happy with my treatment and would explain and help me understand what the next step would be. I have no complaints at all.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

title: Appalling Attitude to Elderly
body:
They were meant to arrange District Nurse - didn't, claimed they had each time rang. When I asked them for district nurses' number they did then finally ring them but logs showed that was first time
Then refused to help 90yo get covid booster
They don't bother with annual health checks and happy to have no contact for years with aged patients
